# Unit 04: Partial Derivatives

YAY!
![003c5ec8.png](003c5ec8-kl2ssw7r.png)

It's literally just differentiating with respect to one variable and not the other. There are also some notation shortcuts, so we don't have to write as much. 
!!! danger differentiation rules
Sometimes, the standard differentiation rules don't apply, resulting in a function that can't be evaluated at the point we need. In this case, we **must** use the formal definition of partial derivatives, to see if the partial derivative actually exists.
!!!

!!! danger partial derivatives
a function's partial derivative can exist at a point, while being discontinuous at that point! differentiable does not imply continuous in multiple dimensions!
!!!

![3c2b8d87.png](3c2b8d87-kl2ssw7r.png)

Importantly, unlike in single-variable functions, differentiability does not imply continuity.

![3ad6299a.png](3ad6299a-kl2ssw7r.png)

So this means, if you take derivatives with respect to x and y, as long as they are both continuous, the order doesn't matter. This extends to higher order derivatives as well.

If the $k$-th partial derivatives of $f$ are continuous, then we write
$$
f \in C^k
$$
and say "$f$ is in class $C^k$".

![634ec23d.png](634ec23d-kl2ssw7r.png)

The tangent plane is really just an extension of the linear approximation of the function.

In higher orders, the above notation gets tedious.
It's better to have everything in a dot product of vectors.
So the **gradient** is the vector of all the partial derivatives evaluated at $\vec{a}$.

![a90aba1a.png](a90aba1a-kl2ssw7r.png)
